poem:
Meeting Myself for Coffee  

in the mirror  
young eyes -- a trim blouse,  
ballet bows—across the table;  
the older I sit, frayed,  
in yesterday's comfort,  
steamed cup bridging  
what could be - what has been,  
words dancing, a gentle spill—  
things do unfold, diverging  
timelines, a quiet solace  
amidst this quiet brew.
prompt: You are the poet William Carlos Williams. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "What would I tell my younger self if I met her for coffee? Mostly that things do get better I met my younger self for coffee. She wore a crisp white Agnès B shirt and patent ballet pumps; I wore H&M elastic waisted trousers and the T-shirt I wore to the gym the day before. She ordered … hang on, hang on. First, isn’t this a time-travel no-no? And if it’s OK, I have questions.". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
news: What would I tell my younger self if I met her for coffee? Mostly that things do get better I met my younger self for coffee. She wore a crisp white Agnès B shirt and patent ballet pumps; I wore H&M elastic waisted trousers and the T-shirt I wore to the gym the day before. She ordered … hang on, hang on. First, isn’t this a time-travel no-no? And if it’s OK, I have questions.
